issue.title: Datadog NTP
issue.body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] I checked the documentation and found no answer;
- [X] I checked to make sure that this issue has not already been filed;
- [X] This is not an ad/bug report.

### Problem description

According to https://github.com/DataDog/datadog-agent/issues/1532#issuecomment-381691058, Datadog uses NTP servers as part of their analytics.  In my logs, they're of the form `#.datadog.pool.ntp.org`, where `#` is currently some small integer (I've recently seen 1-3, but IIRC, perhaps upto 6?).

### Proposed solution

I've been running `datadog$important` for months in both user DNS & content filterlists, & those have never broken anything, but, conservatively `|datadog.pool.ntp.org^` should do just this.

### Additional information

_No response_

comment.body:
From personal experience, based on that I run an NTP server that is part of "NTP Pool", blocking an NTP server entirely would have only small bits of tracking to remove (Provided the NTP server is a normally operating one; Something called "DataDog" does sound odd indeed).

There'd normally also be a significant benefits-to-problems tradeoff, but since DataDog doesn't seem to me to be used by specific device brands (whether it be bedroom watches, set-top boxes, etc.), that'd not be a significant factor in this.

The most cautious entry I can come up with would be `|datadog.pool.ntp.org|$dnsrewrite=pool.ntp.org`, but I'll let the rest of Team AdGuard give 2nd/2rd/nth Opinions on this.

comment.body: With AdGuard VPN set to Denmark, it seemed at first sight to be something that could've been fixed with simply `$generichide`, but the cause seems to be much more complicated than simply whitelisting `##.ad-row` and `##.panorama`. So I'll let the higher-ranking members at Team AdGuard handle it.

comment.body:
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has been open for 4 days with no activity.
Unfortunately, our resources are limited and we can not always take the time to respond to requests about websites that are not popular enough. The issue will be closed if no further activity occurs.
Please note, that AdGuard Filters is an open-source project that is used by different content blockers and we welcome contributions. If you have some technical knowledge about how websites work, you are welcome to create a pull request following [these instructions](https://github.com/AdguardTeam/AdguardFilters/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md).

issue.title: blog.livedoor.jp

labels.name: A: Problematic
labels.description: Issues, which cannot be resolved easily

issue.body:
# Sorry. The website is infected by AdShield, Inc.

Unfortunately, It is complicated to resolve with a regular adblock rule because the website is being protected by service of Ad-Shield that is an anti-adblock company.

## Userscript Installation
Please block Ad-Shield advertisement by installing [microShield userscript](https://github.com/List-KR/microShield).
Please check its installation guideline written in English by visiting [this URL](https://github.com/List-KR/microShield/blob/main/README.md).

If you can understand Korean language, please refer https://community.list-kr.com/docs/AdGuard/Userscripts/microShield.

## Still Have a Problem?
An issue is occurred when the userscript is applied, please report to [this issue tracker](https://github.com/List-KR/microShield/issues).
Please report to [here](https://github.com/AdguardTeam/AdguardFilters/issues/175394) if other issue.
